subject: Re: [junit] RE: Isolation or Collaboration
msgSnippet: ... I have here an interface with about 180 [1] methods, of which maybe ten fail can be invoked at all times without any prerequisites . (EG three of them are
messageBody:
On Wednesday 25 May 2005 03:10, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> >
> > These examples seem to fall into one category: an object
> > representing a resource we have released.
>
> Not necessarily.
>
> Take one of your classes with more than ten methods.
>
> Can you really say that all the public methods of this class can be invoked
> at all time without any pre-requisite?
>
> I would be very surprised if the answer was yes (it would mean your
> application is basically based on a bunch of static methods acting on
> stateless objects).

I have here an interface with about 180 [1] methods, of which maybe ten
fail "can be invoked at all times without any prerequisites". (EG
three of them are a transaction-oriented begin/commit/abort family.)

A bunch of at-any-timers deal with adding stuff (mostly triples, some
name bindings) and removing stuff (ditto); then there's a bunch of
methods probing the stuff (list-satisfying-pattern, does-it-contain,
etc).

Now, one might reasonably say 180 was a tad too many. (It's not *quite*
that bad, because there's a bunch of families of methods differing only
in the type of there last argument - int/real/float/double/long/short/char
/byte/String/Object, pah - so really there's one abstract method and a
clump of overloadings). It's not clear that there's a better solution,
though. For this use, anyway.

[1] "One HUNdred and EIGHTy!" in a Bullseye voice.

--
Chris "jena.sourceforge.net" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
